questions.questionText: Which organization is the central bank of India?
questions.explanation: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is the central bank of India. It was established on April 1, 1935, and nationalized on January 1, 1949. Its headquarters is in Mumbai.

questions.questionText: When was the Reserve Bank of India established?
questions.explanation: The Reserve Bank of India was established on April 1, 1935, under the Reserve Bank of India Act, 1934. It was nationalized on January 1, 1949.

questions.questionText: Who is the current Governor of RBI as of 2024?
questions.explanation: Shaktikanta Das has been serving as the Governor of RBI since December 2018. He is the 25th Governor of the Reserve Bank of India.

questions.questionText: Which is the largest public sector bank in India?
questions.explanation: State Bank of India (SBI) is the largest public sector bank in India in terms of assets, deposits, branches, and employees. It was formed in 1955.

questions.questionText: The repo rate is the rate at which:
questions.explanation: Repo rate is the rate at which the Reserve Bank of India lends money to commercial banks. It is a key monetary policy tool used to control inflation and liquidity.

questions.questionText: When was GST implemented in India?
questions.explanation: Goods and Services Tax (GST) was implemented in India on July 1, 2017. It replaced multiple indirect taxes and brought the concept of 'One Nation, One Tax'.

questions.questionText: Who is the Chairman of the GST Council?
questions.explanation: The Union Finance Minister is the Chairman of the GST Council. The council also includes Finance Ministers of all states as members.

questions.questionText: The Union Budget is presented in Parliament under which Article of the Constitution?
questions.explanation: Article 112 of the Indian Constitution deals with the Annual Financial Statement (Union Budget). It requires the President to lay before Parliament a statement of estimated receipts and expenditure.

questions.questionText: The fiscal year in India runs from:
questions.explanation: The fiscal year (financial year) in India runs from April 1 to March 31. The Union Budget is usually presented on February 1.

questions.questionText: Who was the Finance Minister of India during the 1991 economic reforms?
questions.explanation: Dr. Manmohan Singh was the Finance Minister during the 1991 economic reforms under Prime Minister P.V. Narasimha Rao. He later became the Prime Minister of India (2004-2014).

questions.questionText: The economic reforms of 1991 are commonly known as:
questions.explanation: The economic reforms of 1991 are known as LPG reforms - Liberalization, Privatization, and Globalization. These reforms opened up the Indian economy to the world.

questions.questionText: NITI Aayog was established in which year?
questions.explanation: NITI Aayog (National Institution for Transforming India) was established on January 1, 2015, replacing the Planning Commission. It serves as a policy think tank.
GDP stands for Gross Domestic Product. It is the total value of all goods and services produced within a country in a specific time period, usually a year. It is a key indicator of economic health.

questions.questionText: The symbol ₹ for Indian Rupee was adopted in which year?
questions.explanation: The symbol ₹ for Indian Rupee was officially adopted on July 15, 2010. It was designed by D. Udaya Kumar and combines the Devanagari 'र' and Latin 'R'.

questions.questionText: When was demonetization of ₹500 and ₹1000 notes announced?
questions.explanation: Demonetization of ₹500 and ₹1000 notes was announced on November 8, 2016, by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The objective was to curb black money, counterfeit currency, and corruption.

questions.questionText: Which note is issued by the Government of India and not RBI?
questions.explanation: ₹1 note (and ₹1 coin) is issued by the Government of India (Ministry of Finance), not by the Reserve Bank of India. All other currency notes are issued by RBI.

questions.questionText: What is measured by the Consumer Price Index (CPI)?
questions.explanation: Consumer Price Index (CPI) measures inflation by tracking changes in prices of a basket of goods and services consumed by households. It indicates the change in purchasing power of money.
FDI stands for Foreign Direct Investment. It refers to investment made by a foreign individual or company in business interests located in another country, involving long-term investment and control.
